content.title: Aqua Palace, luxury and voluptuousness for all

introduction.small: At the heart of Venetian life, Aqua Palace Hotel offers luxury services while keeping the prices down.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Aqua Palace, luxury and voluptuousness for all

paragraphs.text:
Only a few minutes away from both St. Mark's Square and the Rialto Bridge, the Aqua Palace Hotel is conveniently located in the Castello district, the largest and most central of all sestieri (areas of the historic part of town). Exuding chic without showing it, most rooms and suites offer views of the Rio della Guerra canal and are elegantly decorated with that typically Italian sense of refinement. The staff will care for your every need and will be able to assist if this is one of your first trips to the capital of the Veneto region. With so many restaurants, museums and other cultural venues around the corner, it may be tough to plan accordingly. Fear not though. Aqua Palace is at once romantic with its subdued lighting, chic chandeliers and classic Venetian architecture, and peaceful, as it is not situated on one of the main traffic arteries. It is an ideal haven of peace where you can recharge your batteries before or after a day spent wandering the gorgeous streets of the Most Serene.

content.title: Da Fiore, high-flying Venetian gastronomy

introduction.small: This old local trattoria was turned into a starred restaurant, shedding a light on regional gastronomy.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Da Fiore, high-flying Venetian gastronomy

paragraphs.text:
In Venice, the Da Fiore restaurant is a family affair, namely the Martins'. The daughter works the lobby, the dad table service, the son at the register and Mara, the mom, in the kitchen. The reputation of this old trattoria, typical of the city, has broken new grounds and spread beyond Italian borders: it has earned its first Michelin star.
Under the vaulted ceiling reminiscent of old Venetian taverns, and with one of the canals in sight through the windows, the chef offers creative and personal cuisine with local flavours. Follow on the regulars and their habits and create your own menu: in antipasti, mushroom and shrimp salad with black truffle, then stewed chicken and guinea fowl lasagna with pumpkin and bacon. The meal could then include some Venetian black calamari served with white corn polenta, and Fiore tiramisu for dessert. Access a higher level of gourmet knowledge with cooking classes by Mara Martin. Stimulate your palate!

content.title: The Jewish ghetto of Venice, a multicultural melting pot

introduction.small: Go off to explore an unknown side of the Serene: it was actually in the Cannaregio district that the first “ghetto” in history was established.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Jewish ghetto of Venice, a multicultural melting pot

paragraphs.text:
In 2016, upon the celebration of the 500 years of existence of the Venice ghetto, many cultural events brought back the tumultuous past of the city. In 1516, on the initiative of the city's Doges, Jews gathered in the first ghetto in history, on the site of a former foundry - the word "geto" originally designated the place where scoria from neighbouring factories was rejected.
The growing population and ban on settling outside of the ghetto saw the birth of the city's tallest buildings of up to eight floors, an exception in Venice. On Campo di Ghetto Nuovo square you will find the Holocaust Memorial and the Ebraico Jewish Museum of Venice. You can also visit a few of the five synagogues, referred to as "Scuole" - among them, do not miss the Ponentina o Spagnola and the Levantina, the two most remarkable. At the entrance of the neighbourhood, you can also see the locations of the gates that once closed the ghetto.

content.title: Santa Maria della Salute, for the love of the Virgin Mary

introduction.small: Dedicated to the Virgin Mary, Santa Maria della Salute Basilica holds a special place in the heart of the Venetians. Discover a symbolic monument.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Santa Maria della Salute, for the love of the Virgin Mary

paragraphs.text:
As you reach Venice by vaporetto, you will catch a glimpse of Santa Maria della Salute Basilica, gem of Venetian architecture adorned with two domes and bell towers that about a hundred statues surround with harmony. The main facade, in classical style, is decorated with half columns while the rest of the building is Baroque-inspired. Once inside, a large staircase takes you to the heart of a large central area, surrounded by six chapels richly decorated with paintings by Tintoretto and Titian. In front of your eyes, the marble floor with geometric patterns is remarkable. It was in 1630 that the construction of the basilica was decided, in order to appeal to the good graces of the Virgin to put an end to the spread of the ravaging plague at the time. Work of famous architect Baldassare Longhena, the structure was built on marshy ground, which required engineers to regularly stabilize it using wooden stilts. Symbolic representations of Mary are plentiful and especially adorn the high altar.

Santa Maria della Salute Basilica

https://basilicasalutevenezia.it/

content.title: St. Mark's Square: a must

introduction.small: Quite simply because Venice would not be Venice without the Piazza San Marco!

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: St. Mark's Square: a must

paragraphs.text:
Gondolas are moored at the molo (jetty). On the edge of a shimmering lagoon, this is the only square in Venice to be called 'piazza'. All the others are referred to as 'campi'. Bounded by the old Procuratie, huge white-stone arcades circling this emblematic Venetian location, and the Doge's Palace, protected by its belfry and its basilica, St. Mark's Square is the scene of a political, economic, and artistic play that has been held without interruption for centuries, and which has made it famous forever.

Today, it is the diva. It is loved by some and decried by others, but ignored by no one. At each visit, there is the same ritual: a hot chocolate at Café Florian, or a Bellini cocktail at the Terrazza Danieli, while allowing yourself to be gently swept away by the setting for the world's most romantic sunsets.

And do not forget to feed the pigeons, as it seems they bring good luck.

Piazza San Marco
30124 Venezia

content.title: The Lido: immortalised by literature and the cinema

introduction.small: A narrow strip of sand has become a land of legends over the years.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Lido: immortalised by literature and the cinema

paragraphs.text:
For a long time, it was just a 12-kilometre-long sandbank over which Lord Byron rode at a gallop. Then, when sea bathing became fashionable, Europe discovered the Lido and it became a seaside resort. Palaces, like the Excelsior and the Grand Hotel des Bains, and Liberty-style villas appeared along the beach, automobiles, too. The Lido is still the only place in Venice where you can drive around.

Its sea mists, between a sirocco and a breeze, inspired Thomas Mann's novel Death in Venice, which Luchino Visconti made into a film half a century later, according him a persistent romantic aura. Today, it is by bike that we go down to the pinewood of Alberoni to collect shells. Then, maybe a nap in a deckchair, before going to drink a Prosecco at the Quattro Fontane, where film makers of the Venice Mostra may still be found today.

content.title: The Rialto Market: a taste of the real Venice

introduction.small: A picturesque stroll in the fish market in the early morning is a must.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Rialto Market: a taste of the real Venice

paragraphs.text:
The Rialto, its bridge, shops, and market are the oldest in Venice. Almost a thousand years old, history in itself! In the Middle Ages, merchants had already begun coming here to sell spices and rice brought from the East. Marco Polo undoubtedly traded here.

But go early in the morning and first, listen to the Venetians: they still communicate in Venetian rather than Italian. Then, let yourself be carried away by the abundance, the succulence of the stalls, from produce-oriented Erbaria to Beccaria and its meat market, and of course famous Pescheria and its iodine flavours. Every morning, the fishermen of the lagoon bring a miraculous catch whose freshness is evident on the firm, gleaming sides of the fish.

Look at these beautiful sea bass, these brilliant sea bream, these baskets of plump prawns and octopus… all the tastes of Venice are here.

Rialto Market

content.title: Burano: a multi-coloured gem

introduction.small: In the lagoon surrounding Venice are multiple islands. Burano is a rare pearl, but it is not the only one.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Burano: a multi-coloured gem

paragraphs.text:
From St. Mark's Square, take the vaporetto for a getaway to the north of the lagoon, and most especially to Burano, an island known for its fishermen and lacemakers. On the main square, amidst its colourful houses, a tradition that has made the reputation of Venice actually survives in one of the last schools in Italy. Needle-worked lace was invented in Burano, and this is also where the famous Venetian stitch was born.

In the 16th century, lace-makers had the idea of ​​no longer pulling on the array of threads they embroidered, but, instead, of drawing and tracking their work on a kind of pattern. Women were the champions in the meticulous task of embroidery, while the men worked glass. Hence, the next stop, the island of Murano, which is famous for its glass-blowers. Their chandeliers illuminate all the palaces of yesterday and today. Murano-blown glass is seeing a new creative splendour, thanks to artists like Jaime Hayon, who are reviving this ancient art.

After this, take a refreshing walk in the country on Torcello. This small island is becoming more and more popular for its authentic charm.

content.title: Hotel Cipriani: a legend

introduction.small: At least once in your lifetime, you should fall asleep and wake up in the most luxurious hotel in Venice.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Hotel Cipriani: a legend

paragraphs.text:
From the tip of Giudecca, the city seems far away. On this island, nature is synonymous with beauty and farniente. When you have long walked the lanes of the Dorsoduro, or been lost in the maze of the Cannaregio quarters, relaxing in the hotel's almost one-hectare park or around the Olympic size swimming pool is a kind of heaven reserved for the happy few. Forget about Renaissance palaces, true 5-star luxury takes hold in a modern palazzo, far from the frenzied historic centre of Venice.

A night's sleep at the Cipriani means waking up in a room whose windows overlook cypress gardens planted with the scent of rosemary. In the morning, the long corridors take you past boudoirs in ochre shades of Fortuny fabrics for breakfast on one of the terraces.

There you are, at the edge of the lagoon… overlooking the lagoon… intimate with the lagoon, and time suddenly freezes…

Francesca, who is the owner of this charming place, has only one word on her lips comfort! Thoughtful and considerate, she is at your disposal to make you feel good and to make sure you enjoy your stay and her establishment as much as possible.

There are six bedrooms, of which two are very romantic attic rooms, and one suite, making things feel more like a family house than a regular hotel. Each room is very spacious, with views over the roofs of the Rialto, Venice's iconic market, or the bell tower of San Cassiano. They all hark back to Italian art, through movie titles, plays, paintings or famous music compositions. The furniture is antique, the silks oriental, and the king size beds.

As breakfast is generally served in your room, you will have no remorse about lingering a little longer on the soft pillows while organising the day's programme.

content.title: The Venice Biennale: an international success

introduction.small: Every two years, Venice becomes the vanguard for contemporary art creation. It is also a stronghold for theatre and cinema.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Venice Biennale: an international success

paragraphs.text:
In odd-numbered years, Venice forgets its magnificent past to invent the future. According to one of the curators of the Biennale, who change with each edition, it offers a more global reflection on the current state of contemporary art. The Venetian Biennale also gives out an award, the Golden Lion, to an artist whose entire career is an achievement.

The headquarters of this contemporary event is the Guardini. It is here, in these splendid English gardens that 28 pavilions of the founding countries and the artists they present are installed. A victim of its success, the Biennale has expanded, taking possession of the Arsenale, and then, little by little, in 'off' mode, it has infiltrated palaces and museums, and is even seen on some small islands like La Certosa and Sant'Elena.

Though some of its biases are, at times, considered extreme, what matter does it make, as long as modernity is honoured and celebrated? Because Venice is a party!

content.title: Oltre il Giardino: a magical place

introduction.small: A little piece of paradise for a romantic getaway.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Oltre il Giardino: a magical place

paragraphs.text:
Behind the door, there is the garden, the olive trees, magnolia, and even the canal. This hotel, which was the home of painter and musician Alma Mahler, successively the wife of composer Gustav Mahler, architect Walter Gropius, and novelist Franz Werfel creates the feeling that every traveller wants to experience: that of being at home. Since then, the house has been turned into a hotel, but you can sense the characteristic Venetian charm and artistic inclinations of its previous occupants.

The owner has furnished the six rooms with furniture and family paintings, and all accommodations overlook the garden outside, a rare feat in the heart of the city. This is where you may read and reread the great authors that Venice has inspired, while listening to Gustav Mahler's symphonies or those of Natanael Berg. Every carefully refined detail is an invitation to a simple, contented happiness.

content.title: Palazzo Grassi: Venice's Museum of Modern Art

introduction.small: At the heart of the city, the palace is owned by the French billionaire François Pinault, who turned it into a museum to house his personal collection.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Palazzo Grassi: Venice's Museum of Modern Art

paragraphs.text:
How does a collection come together? The answer is hung on the walls of the Palazzo Grassi. In 2005, François Pinault bought this palace, already devoted to art, from the Agnelli family.

The French entrepreneur put the Japanese architect Tadao Ando in charge of renovating it and of coming up with a museographic setting that would showcase his collection of more than 2,000 pieces, while respecting the neo-Gothic style of the 18th-century building. The Japanese architect played upon a blueprint that rhymes with harmony. This is the first reason why one should visit this foundation. The second? It brings together, in one place, some of the most important minimalist, post-minimalist, and pop-art artworks, including pieces by Jeff Koons, Takashi Murakami, and Damien Hirst.

Which makes it easier to better understand the coherence and grasp the meaning of these artistic movements. The Pinault Foundation today also occupies an adjacent building, the Punta della Dogana.

content.title: Al Mercà: the best wine bar

introduction.small: At cocktail hour, pop into one of Venice's favourite hangouts.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Al Mercà: the best wine bar

paragraphs.text:
In late afternoon, Venetians like to come to this tiny place in the lively San Polo district and set the world to rights over a glass of wine. Some proclaim loudly that this is the best wine bar in Venice. It is, indeed, undoubtedly one of the best! Here, you remain standing, or even outside like most everybody.

At the bar, order some homemade paninis, delicious sausages, or cod fritters, best paired with a glass of 'Rosso Masieri' or a Spritz – to be enjoyed in moderation – or some fruit juice. The whole counter is laden with delicacies that can be eaten with or without hunger, but always with relish. Conversations start up, anecdotes are exchanged on the square right in front, and, before you know it, you're there for the night.

you care to be seated, you can sit in front of the large barrels that function as tables, or take a spot outside on the steps to philosophize while facing the canal.

The 'Doge's Room' is lined with red brocade, while chandeliers spread a restful, golden light. The 'Fireplace Room' has an opalescent marble mantle. The 'Sala Noire' evokes the spices brought from the East by Renaissance merchants. Each one will bring some romantic charm to your Venetian stay.

In the morning, breakfast is served on the Moroccan terrace overlooking the Santa Maria della Salute basilica, a mere vaporetto stop from St. Mark's Square. After a full day of visits in the evening, you can voluptuously snuggle into the comfortable black leather armchairs of the living room, sipping a glass of Amarone.

content.title: Cà D'Oro alla Vedova: for a light snack

introduction.small: Eating on the run in a typical Venetian atmosphere.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Cà D'Oro alla Vedova: for a light snack

paragraphs.text:
Do not be fooled by the welcome, which is sometimes a little rough. The same family has run this trattoria since the late 19th century, and they have helped make the reputation of Venetian cuisine what it is today. The room is small, so, while waiting for a table, nibble some cicchetti, tapas-like appetisers at the counter, including delicious octopus. More than a restaurant, Cà D'Oro alla Vedova is also a bacaro, a typical place where to have a glass of wine with a few snacks, usually standing at the counter.

The restaurant has also made polpette, meat dumplings, their speciality, which are, it seems, the best of Venice. This is a reward that the linguine with squid ink and the octopus polenta deserve, both for their iodised fragrance (proof of freshness) as that of the very aromatic olive oil.

For dessert, the mamma makes biscuits that you dip in your coffee or, like the Venetians, in your glass of wine.

introduction.small: Living like a Venetian in a resolutely contemporary atmosphere.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Code Name: DD 724

It sounds like a secret code, but it is actually an abbreviation for one of the most discrete, most uncommon designer hotels in Venice. From the street, nothing indicates this Charming House, the DD 724. The number partly gives it away, bringing a somewhat intimate and secretive feel to the premises… Ideal for a romantic stay.

The seven rooms of this small palace have abandoned neo-Gothic style for a refined contemporary decor. Every room, every detail, propels the Venetian art of living into modernity, with brown and beige tones, contemporary furniture with simple lines, and works by current painters such as Raimondo Galeano, Stefania Orrù, and Nazareno Luciano.

At night, throw in a subtle touch of sensuality in the evening with the diffused light of candles, and you will feel as much an inhabitant of Venice as your own hosts.

content.title: Alla Madonna: sure value

introduction.small: A family business dedicated to good food.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Alla Madonna: sure value

Suddenly, we are plunged back into the past. The servers wear great aprons, run with style from one room to another cutting fish and meat at the table, in the finest tradition of the Italian trattoria. What to choose? You are close to the Rialto fish market, so the fish arrive in the kitchen perfectly fresh.

For starters, try the Venetian fish soup with bread crumbs, the sautéed clams or the seafood risotto for the salty fragrance and tasty flavour of the sea that will provide an enduring nostalgic reminiscence. Then you only have to choose among the many pastas and dishes, including excellent Milanese ribs. If you would rather have fish, the fried eel, seabream and grilled red mullet are all very tempting, that is unless you cave in for the lobster and mayo…

Between two services, admire the paintings on the walls, all of which are signed by artists, gifts to the owner and his son, who has now taken over the restaurant.

Upon entry, the tone is set: 'Here, no pizza, lasagne or tourist menu' warns your host in his baritone voice. This small trattoria of the San Polo district offers traditional Venetian home cooking. The menu is developed, depending on the market, around the fish that are among the best in the Rialto market, which is also close by.

Everything feels authentic in the kitchen, which you can witness as you actually enter the restaurant through it! Crab fritters, grilled octopus, filet of John Dory with smoked pumpkin cream and mushrooms, Venetian squid in ink and white polenta, all accompanied with the white wines of Friuli - all are so good they will barely touch your lips. For dessert, pay attention to the chocolate mousse with lime cream, mango and coconut foam. It is best to reserve, as the regulars are numerous - and often famous.

content.title: Campo Santa Margherita: Venice's ‘fairground'

introduction.small: The Campo, symbol of the art of Venetian living, is very lively at night, courtesy of students from nearby universities.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Campo Santa Margherita: Venice's ‘fairground'

paragraphs.text:
Sometimes there's nothing better than the chance discovery of a square after stumbling up an alley, and then finding a seat on the terrace of a café, where you can linger and watch Venetian life go by.

In the morning, just like on a village central square, housewives are doing their shopping in the still-typical shops of Campo Santa Margherita, or in the colourful stalls of its small market. In the afternoon, children play football and, in the evening, students from nearby universities make it their headquarters for pre-dinner drinks. Before heading off to private parties, they remake the world at the Caffe Bar Rosso. This is the time to share a grilled panini or a plate of small fried fish with them.

In summer, under the stars, there are improvised jazz concerts, and legend has it that Chet Baker played here, hence the nearby 'Chet Bar'.

content.title: Do Farai: a 1950s ambiance

introduction.small: The canteen for gondoliers and lovers of Venice: a place not to miss.

This is the restaurant of the gondoliers, whose tournaments are displayed in picture frames on the walls. The room is old, simple, and friendly. In summer, a large terrace is erected in the middle of Campiello dei Squelini. You suddenly feel part of a family celebration.

The Venetians converse from table to table, talking loudly but also respecting your privacy. Dino takes control, Stefano prepares fish. For starters: tuna carpaccio, spider crab or sautéed shrimp with polenta. Next, bigoli in salsa, emblematic Venetian dish with whole wheat, onions and anchovies, or the other Venetian speciality, the veal liver served with mashed potatoes.

Warning: the dish is rich and it is impossible to go without dessert. We adore the sgroppino, a lemon sorbet with emulsified grappa (an Italian eau-de-vie) that Stefano mixes to order.

content.title: La Fenice: a temple of opera

introduction.small: Try to spend at least one evening in this legendary opera house, where the biggest names of the operatic stage have performed.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: La Fenice: a temple of opera

paragraphs.text:
No theatre bears its name so well. Twice destroyed, twice rebuilt, like the phoenix, it always rises from the ashes, identical, with the same flamboyance, the same luxury.

Rossini, Verdi, and Bellini gave the world premieres of their operas on this legendary stage of Italian lyricism, open since 1792. Luchino Visconti also shot the first scenes of his masterpiece Senso here. Certainly, the Fenice lost its flamboyance for a while, but it has found it again. Another renaissance! This Italian-style theatre is enjoying a new lease on life and not just in terms of lyricism. Just look at these balconies adorned with fine layers of gold, the curtains made of rich velvet, the stage itself, radiating with beauty… It would almost overshadow the performers!

There is singing and dancing there. Carolyn Carlson and Pina Bausch are part of the repertoire for each season, and the ghost of María-Felicia García (La Malibran, the Spanish-born French opera singer who left her mark on the location), is always at the forefront to applaud them.

content.title: Peggy Guggenheim Collection: to see again and again

introduction.small: Simply the most famous and most visited museum of modern art in Italy.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Peggy Guggenheim Collection: to see again and again

paragraphs.text:
Peggy Guggenheim is a legend unto herself. An eccentric bohemian, this American millionaire knew, loved, and frequented all the artists of the 20th century. But most importantly, she had an extraordinary eye. Peggy could recognise real talent and locate the one amongst all the paintings that would mark its time.

In 1947, she bought the Venier dei Leoni palace from Luisa Casati. Built in 1748 along the Grand Canal, it was incomplete, with only one floor finished. She made it her residency and, after presenting her collection at the Biennale, installed the works in her new home. This extravagant patron then organised the first Italian exhibitions of Jackson Pollock and Mark Rothko. After her death, she donated the house-museum to the Solomon R. Guggenheim Foundation, which has managed it since, and which organises temporary exhibitions of other artists alongside paintings by Picasso, Léger, and Mondrian, and sculptures by Brancusi and Calder.

Do not miss the room devoted to Peggy Guggenheim's jewellery and glasses: these singular creations have inspired many jewellers and opticians over the years.

Peggy Guggenheim Collection
Palazzo Venier dei Leoni
Dorsoduro 704
30123 Venezia

+39 041 240 5411

https://www.guggenheim-venice.it/en/the-museum/﻿
